headline: Rep. McSally: We have a historic diplomatic opening in NoKo
subHeadline: House Armed Services Committee member and Arizona Congresswoman Martha McSally weighs in on joint military exercise between U.S. and South Korea and upcoming summit between President Trump and Kim Jong Un.

utterances.speaker: NEIL CAVUTO, HOST
utterances.sentences: So, could it be as simple as a case of cold feet, and maybe the North Koreans getting a little nervous about giving away so much so early, or the global perception that they are? Who better than to get a read of this than a woman who has visited the country, will be visiting the country again?  Arizona Republican Congresswoman Martha McSally, a key member, by the way, of the House Armed Services Committee.  Congresswoman, good to have you on.  REP. MARTHA MCSALLY, R—ARIZONA: Good to be on, Neil. Thanks. Yes, I'm going there next weekend actually. I`m leading a congressional delegation.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Be safe.

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: I will.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Well, what's going on here, you think?

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: Well, look, it's hard to tell. Could be just some posturing and trying to show strength coming up to the summit. But we have also seen in the past, 1992 and 2000 and 2007, where they had a lot of nice words about moving towards more of a peace, and then it really ended up being nothing and they backtracked to their normal oppressive, belligerent regime.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: So, they lie. They have a history of lying.

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: They have a history of lying. Right? And, so in this case, you talk about trust, but verify. It's distrust and deeply verify. And we have a diplomatic opening that is historic, certainly, haven't seen in 65 years, thanks to the maximum pressure campaign by the Trump administration.  But the hard work is in front of us. Capability -- you know, threat equals capability plus intent. And right now capabilities are still there, as was just pointed out. And the words have changed a little bit. But the hard work is really in the front.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But if Kim Jong Un is saying that I have no interest in meeting with my South Korean counterpart, I mean, do we still go to our wedding?

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: Well, I think there is still a lot of diplomatic efforts going on behind the scenes in order to prepare for this. So let`s see how the next days unfold. They have an ongoing exercise that's going to continue until the end of the month. They have an air force exercise with the --

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: You mean our joint military exercises with the South Koreans?

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: By the way, is there anything that we have been doing different delay that would have prompted this response?

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: No. We, in fact, delayed the initial exercise until after the Olympics, you know, in a goodwill -- but they knew it was coming.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Did we tell them it was coming?

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: I'm sure they know, yes.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Something to me, congresswoman, seems to have either been miscommunicated or that they didn't see coming, or, to your earlier point, maybe just doing what they have done so often in the past.

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: Yes.  The Air Force exercises started yesterday. And they go until the 25th. And so that's a little bit of a shift of a new exercise that started.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: So, we haven't been any more provocative in any way?

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: No, not at all.  I mean, these exercises are yearly. They're just based on our working with our Korean counterparts to make sure that we are ready to go, we have got interoperability, command-and-control. This is what we do all the time.  And we shouldn't stop them. Look, if they are trying to get to us stop these exercises, when they haven't changed one thing, that would be dangerous. I would not advise that.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: So, you wouldn't advise that we change -- not stop the exercises, but either, I don't know, don't make them as dramatic? I don't know.

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: No way.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: Stay the course now. Keep up the maximum pressure campaign. We have a diplomatic opening for sure. But the vice grips need to keep being very strong until they actually change their behavior, that they would allow a full denuclearization of the peninsula that is verifiable.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But wasn`t the subject of what the meeting on June 12 was going to be about, changing behavior then?

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: Yes, but Secretary Pompeo has been over there a couple times now and they`re doing a lot of groundwork behind the scenes in order to prepare for that meeting on June 12. So, again, this is -- there`s a long time between now and June 12. And a lot of things can happen diplomatically. And the administration needs to make the decision. We always had to be ready to walk away.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: President Trump has said that many times. This is a historic opportunity.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But we didn`t think walk away ahead of the meeting, right?  So, maybe it's all settled, but do you think the Chinese are playing any role here, or there's pressure in North Korea that Kim Jong Un has given the impression or given the store away before even sitting down?

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: I think he certainly needs to continue to show strength. He's got his own internal politics and his own regime dynamics going on. It's hard to tell.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: -- any resistance, congresswoman, to the overtures he's made, now, he doesn't make them, I know, in a vacuum?

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But that the perception is that, boy, between the release of the hostages, between the denuclearization commitment --

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: Right, that he`s showing weakness, potentially.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: And, again, that doesn't surprise me. I'm not saying -- I can't tell you about classified information I have about what they're actually talking about internally.  So, he is trying to, I think, show up to the negotiations potentially with greater strength, instead of weakness. We are certainly in a position of strength.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But your trip is still one? Nothing has been canceled?

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: I`m still heading over there.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Is there going to be someone to meet you on the other side or --

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: We're not going north. We're staying -- we're going to the DMZ.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right. But if they're worried that all of the sudden the North doesn't want to meet with them, would your meeting be pointless?

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: I think it's really important for me to get on the ground with this delegation, talk to the troops, talk to the embassy, see what's actually happening real time and get a real sense firsthand.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Well, have they talked to you, congresswoman, to say, we don't know what's up?

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: We have been talking about our plans for our trip, but we will see when we get on the ground.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: The president, of course, has been making very clear in the State Department, we're still going, we don't see anything changing.

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Is that official read, the official read, you think, we should be responding?

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: I think, right now -- again, this is just new news. We need to see what happens in the days ahead. And I think it's right to continue to plan towards June 12. But we always have to be willing to walk away. And the president has been very clear about that. We are not giving away the farm. We have very clear objectives of making sure that no American city is going to be held hostage with a nuclear weapon by North Korea. We will use all elements of national power in order to stop that from happening, economic, diplomatic, and military if necessary.   And he needs to change his behavior. He's got an opportunity. Let's see what path he chooses to take.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: While I have got you here, we have a bulletin coming in that the European Union is looking at efforts to salvage the Iran deal following our withdrawal. In other words, they have not joined us.

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: That is England, France, Germany. Doesn't say anything about Russia and China. On our backing away from that. But they are trying to salvage it.

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: I don't know what that means. It's a crappy deal. We have said that all along. They have had 16 months in order to address these very real shortfalls of the sunset clause in seven years  They have a patient path to a bomb that it doesn't address their ballistic missile development, and it doesn't address all their maligned activities and destabilizing activities. And they're the largest state sponsor of terror. And so all of these things are causing Iran to continue to -- whether it's in Yemen or Syria or attacking Israel -- this is all because of an influx of cash that the Obama administration allowed for them. The Europeans have to decide whether they're going to be with us and they're going to be with stabilization or they're going to be looking through green glasses only about doing business with Iran. And they are going to have some tough decisions going forward. And I hope they choose correctly to stand with us.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Congresswoman, thank you very much. Safe travels.

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY
utterances.sentences: Thanks a lot. Copy: Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, Inc. Copyright CQ-2018 ASC Services II Media, LLC. utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY

utterances.speaker: MCSALLY

utterances.utterance: While I have got you here, we have a bulletin coming in that the European Union is looking at efforts to salvage the Iran deal following our withdrawal. In other words, they have not joined us.
